\f0\fs28 \cf0 Imagine learning for the first
eighteen years of your life that the earth

is flat. All through elementary school and
high school you grow up hearing about the

flat earth we live on and doing boring flat-earth
physics homework and then (if you're lucky

enough) you get to college and PSYCH!
\f1 for the first time they show you a globe

and say "sorry for lying, the earth is actually
round".\

\
Well, this is, unfortunately, exactly what

we do with\
\

1) Gravity\
You probably learned that objects attract

each other based on their mass so you probably
grew up thinking that light can't possibly

be affected by gravity because light is massless.
I know I did. Well guess what? The source

of gravity is not mass - it's energy and momentum,
which light certainly has (of course, regular

matter does too). So not only does light get
bent passing by a star or planet or black

hole, but light attracts the planet or star
or black hole in return (to be sure, it's

only a very very small amount. But a small
amount is not zero). Anyway, the point is

that Newton's law of gravitation is just an
approximation - good enough to get us to the

moon, but not perfect. General relativity
is better.\

\
2) Special Relativity\

Speaking of the moon, you probably also learned
that if a sheep is moving 2 mph relative to

a train and that train is moving 2 mph in
the same direction relative to the ground,

then the sheep is moving four mph relative
to the ground. 2mph+2mph=4mph, right? FALSE.

Experiments in special relativity have confirmed
that velocities don't simply add together

and so the sheep will in fact be moving very
very ever-so-slightly slower than four mph

relative to the ground. And the formula that
correctly predicts this deviation from just

adding the velocities is (v1+v2)/(1+v1*v2/c^2).
It's not a very big effect, but then again,

the earth looks pretty flat, doesn't it?\
\

But the earth isn't flat: if I walk 10,000km
away from my cat, and you continue on walking

10,000km more, you're NOT 20,000km away from
my cat. You're just 12,750km away\'85 in fact,

the farthest on earth you can get from ANYTHING
on earth is 12,750km. It's the "earthly distance-limit",

though we normally call it the diameter of
the earth. And similarly, when you try to

add two velocities together, there's a "cosmic
speed limit" of 300,000,000m/s - that is,

the speed of light.\
\

So, just because to our eyes the earth looks
flat, velocities look like they simply add

together, and light looks like it doesn't
attract gravitationally, is that an excuse

to mislead ourselves and our children about
the true nature of things?}

comments.text:
+galerius07 The equation for momentum is p=ymv (shown in the video towards 
the beginning). The y is gamma, called the Lorentz factor or the gamma 
factor. You can look up the formula for it online and check that when v 
approaches c, y approaches infinity. Hence, at v=c, you'll have the 
equation for momentum be infinity multiplied by 0 (since m=0 for light), 
which is not necessarily 0 (it depends on the relative sizes of 0 and 
infinity). This Lorentz factor is also present in the energy equation, 
E=ymc^2, so that's why light can have energy as well. By equating things 
together, we find that E=pc for light.

comments.text:
Your description of how to measure velocity is flawed.  It is very easy to 
measure an object's velocity even if you never actually observe the object 
to be moving instantaneously.  Velocity is a change in position over time.  
If you observe an object at one point, and then some time later observe it 
to be literally occupying different space at a later time, it's velocity is 
simply the change in that position divided by the time between 
observations.  You don't ever have to observe it in motion to make that 
calculation.

The point is, you cannot measure an object's velocity with a single 
measurement because velocity is a CHANGE in position.  You cannot known the 
CHANGE in position by only observing it's current position.  You must also 
have observed a previous position.  So when you make a single observation 
of a particle to determine its velocity, if you do not have a reference for 
comparison, you simply cannot make the calculation.  Velocity is unknown; 
not zero.

and gluons, which are all moving very fast, in fact most of the mass 
(something like 80%) of the orange is made up of the energy of the 
interaction of the quarks and gluons.

While we know that most of the orange's mass is made up of movement of the 
quarks and gluons and some contribution from the protons, neutrons and 
electrons, is there a rest mass of quarks or electrons?

Maybe, but we don't know. Most if the "rest mass" of the electron and quark 
(which only makes up a small fraction of the orange) is thought to be from 
interaction with the Higgs field, but this is still an interaction, so you 
could sort of think of it as movement. In the very early universe it was 
though that the Higgs field did not interact with particles and essentially 
everything was massless in the same way that the photon is massless. Do I 
understand what that means? Not really, but that is what physics says.

Finally, the neutrino, which is very similar to the electron without an 
electric charge, has been measured to have a rest mass much smaller than an 
electron. The current mathematical representation of physics says that 
neutrinos should not have a mass, which means that there is physics at work 
that we do not understand.

So, it is possible that mass can exist without momentum, but so far every 
time we have looked closer, it is particles moving around that produces the 
mass. Maybe we will understand it one day, but I do not think it will be 
anytime soon.

Hey James M, in fact, the correct relationship from Special Relativity is:
E^2 = m^2 * c^4 + p^2 * c^2,
where m is the rest mass, p is momentum, and E is energy. Look at two cases:
1) Light: Rest mass is zero, m=0. Energy is then E=p*c. Energy comes from 
light's movement (actually, it cannot stand still), as it does for all 
massless particles.
2) A chunk of material in your room: It's velocity, v, is tiny compared to 
speed of light c. Therefore the momentum is approximately p=m*v, and the 
second term is tiny compared to the first. You can approximate the formula 
then, obtaining:
E = m * c^2 + (m* v^2)/2
(note I took the square root of the first formula). This is just your 
Newtonian kinetic energy, plus the Einstein's part m*c^2, which represents 
the relativistic content of the rest mass and does not influence Newtonian 
movement since it is just a constant. It is this part of the energy however 
which gets converted (or at least part of it does) into heat energy when an 
atomic bomb goes off.

comments.text:
Light travels at the same speed whether measured by an observer in the car 
or by an observer standing by the side of the road.  Speed is measured in 
meters per second (or any distance and time units you prefer).  A meter of 
space is a constant, but it turns out that time is variable.  Put a clock 
with sufficient resolution and accuracy in the car and another next to the 
observer at the roadside, and the clock in the car will run slower than the 
one at the roadside.

So, if you measure the speed of the light coming from the car when standing 
by the road, and you measure the speed of the same light while in the car, 
you will come up with the same figure.  Time dilation accounts for not 
measuring the 100 km/h difference you might have expected.

An experiment was performed in 1971 by flying atomic clocks around the 
world, reuniting them with identical clocks that remained on the ground and 
comparing their time.  The difference in elapsed time, measured by the 
clocks, agreed with Einstein's prediction.  Other experiments have 
confirmed this too.

The Higgs boson has a "mexican hat" shaped potential energy for the value

Today, the Higgs field is sitting on the bottom of the valley, |ϕ| = v. So

regular, well behaved field with positive mass squared. But it wasn't 
always this way. In the early universe, the potential didn't look like that 
picture -- the potential was modified by the high temperature of the 
universe. So, it looked something like this:

cf.ydcdn. net/ 1.0.1. 30/images/main/paraboloid.jpg

The lowest energy state was when the Higgs was sitting in the bottom of the 
bowl,  |ϕ| = 0. Here, too, there's an energy cost to changing the value of 
the field and the Higgs is a good, well behaved field.

However, at some point the temperature dropped below some critical value 
and the field went from looking like a bowl to looking like a Mexican hat. 
When that happened, there was no longer an energy cost to change the value 
of the field. Instead, there was an energy *gain*, just like in the 
inverted pendulum case! At this exact moment, the universe has a tachyon. 
Very quickly the field "rolls off" to the newly formed valley and 
everything stabilizes again.

This process is termed Tachyon condensation. Just like the pendulums could 
spontaneously fall down and oscillate widely (we call the oscillations 
"particles"), the Higgs can roll off to the new value that minimizes the 
potential energy and produce a bunch of particles in the process. 

That's what a tachyon is: an object in a description of a theory with an 
unstable ground state.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+Smithy0013 Yes, that's what makes it common. Even a guy who gave a talk in 
my department said that. It really is a misconception though, and I'll 
explain why.

The most fundamental description of reality that we know and understand is 
quantum field theory. As the name indicates, this is a theory of fields, 
extended wavelike objects, rather than pointlike particles. Indeed, if you 
try to think of tachyons as pointlike objects, you might conclude that they 
move faster than the speed of light... but that rests on the assumption 
that you can indeed recover the naive billiard ball-like "particle" 
behavior from the underlying field theory. It turns out that you can only 
really do that for particles with a nonnegative mass squared. 

I understand that you don't want to take me at my word so I'll link two 
authoritative places that agree with me:

1. John Baez does the field analysis properly and demonstrates that there 
are two types of tachyon "waves":

math.ucr. edu/home/baez/physics/ParticleAndNuclear/tachyons.html

One is a delocalized disturbance with crests that do move faster than light 
but which are useless for transmitting information because it's delocalized 
anyway. The other is simply a pulse traveling at exactly the speed of 
light. It *must* be this way for tachyons to even make sense as a concept. 
Quantum field theory takes causality to be an axiom, which would be 
violated by any kind of faster than light information transfer.

2. Lenny Susskind discusses the tachyons which appear in naive 
quantizations of (bosonic) string theory:

watch?v=gCyImLu0HSI&t=58m51s

He puts it far less charitably than I would: "only crackpots think that 
tachyons move faster than the speed of light" :)

He gives a cute example which neatly encapsulates what a tachyon is. 
"Mass", in quantum field theory, is merely an energy price for a field to 
have a nonzero value at a given point. Imagine a bunch of pendulums hanging 
from a metal bar. Let's say that my "field" at a given position is the 
displacement from the vertical of the pendulum at that point. There's an 
energy price to displace each pendulum, that depends on the mass of the 
bob, the acceleration due to gravity, the length of the rod and that sort 
of thing. That's a positive mass squared. Now invert every pendulum: you'll 
have an extremely unstable situation, but that's the point. If you displace 
a pendulum from the vertical, there's no energy price -- in fact, you *gain* 
kinetic energy by doing that. That's a negative mass squared. However, in 
either case there is a maximum propagation velocity for signals which is 
really the speed of sound in the metal bar. There's no way that simply 
inverting the pendulums allows you to exceed the "cosmic speed limit" for 
this simple system, which is the physical intuition behind Baez's 
mathematical proof.
